Explanation: The doctor effectively gathered relevant information about the patient's abdominal pain by asking specific questions regarding the onset, location, nature, and associated symptoms of the pain.
The doctor asked about the onset of the abdominal pain by inquiring when it started, which allowed the patient to provide the relevant information that it started suddenly last night.
The doctor specifically asked the patient to point to the area of pain, which directly addresses the location of the abdominal pain.
The doctor did not ask about the severity of the abdominal pain on a scale of 1 to 10, which is crucial for assessing the intensity of the patient's symptoms.
The doctor did not specifically ask about the quality of the pain, such as its sharpness or cramping nature, which are crucial details for understanding the patient's symptoms.
The doctor did not ask any questions regarding the radiation of the pain, which is important to determine if the pain is localized or if it spreads to other areas.
The doctor did not specifically ask about factors that alleviate or exacerbate the pain, such as whether movement worsens the pain or if over-the-counter painkillers provide any relief.
The doctor specifically asked about other symptoms accompanying the abdominal pain, which led the patient to mention nausea and mild fever.
The doctor specifically asked about changes in bowel habits, which directly led to the patient revealing their constipation.
The doctor did not ask any questions specifically related to appetite changes, such as whether the patient has experienced a decreased appetite.
The doctor did not ask about any previous episodes of similar pain, which is crucial for understanding the patient's medical history.
The doctor specifically asked about current medications, including over-the-counter medications, which led the patient to disclose their occasional use of ibuprofen for headaches.
The doctor did not specifically inquire about the patient's past medical history regarding hypertension or its management with medication.
The doctor specifically asked about recent surgeries or medical procedures, which allowed the patient to disclose their past appendectomy.
The doctor specifically asked about family history of medical conditions, which led the patient to disclose that their mother has diabetes and their father had hypertension.
The doctor did not ask any questions related to the patient's occupation, which is necessary to gather a complete medical history.
The doctor specifically asked about alcohol use, which allowed the patient to provide the relevant information about their drinking habits.
The doctor did not ask any questions regarding the use of illicit drugs, which is necessary to determine the patient's history in that area.
The doctor directly asked the patient about smoking habits, which allowed the patient to confirm that they have never smoked.
The doctor specifically asked about the patient's exercise routine, which led to the patient revealing that they walk three times a week.
The doctor did not ask any questions related to the patient's diet or eating habits, which would be necessary to obtain information about their dietary practices.
The doctor specifically asked about allergies to medications, which led the patient to disclose their allergy to penicillin.
